threads.com:
I think I have found a solution to the AI problem, or at least a potentially beneficial application of AI to protect artists that are unwilling to have their intellectual property abused for AI training.
AI proponents usually argue that "styles can't be copywritten!", and that gives them every right to train your art style with AI models. This is true, but it is incredibly subjective for a human to determine where one person's style ends and where another person's style begins. Legally, this murkiness makes it difficult to properly defend an artist's artstyle.
But as we have seen, AIs have no trouble understanding what an artist's distinctive 'style' is. An AI can clearly differentiate between two different styles, and can mathematically determine the difference between them. Since AI doesn't actually create its own unique art styles, but just meshes them together, an AI could also determine what percentage of an image is generated using copywritten material.
With this logic, why shouldn't we push for AI-assisted copyright protections on artstyles to defend artistic copyright from AI scrapers?

Let’s have an AI art challenge.

Rules are simple.

The challenger chooses an existing piece of artwork, and then describes it. The challengee then feeds the description to one or more AI image generators. The challengee can make whatever changes to the description that they need to try and match the original.

The challenger will then tell the challengee where the AI failed to match the original, and they can make whatever changes they need to try to match the original.

We will repeat this process as many times as is needed until the challengee either matches the original, or until they give up.

>>6376972
I am quite experienced in this so let me tell you:

Go to thispersondoesnotexist.com and draw the first face that appears, no excuses, even if the one that appears is an ugly pajeeta.

How do you draw it? The way you prefer. If you want to use construction use construction but use the method that suits you best and gives you best results. You will know what gives you results by trying different things, experiment, don't be afraid of doing things wrong.

With what do you draw? If you like drawing with pen draw with pen, if you like drawing with brush draw with brush. Use the medium you are comfiest or you want to excel.

Now there are two ways of practice that you must do to become proficient:
1) Make the drawing as loosely as possible, put the maximum of expression to it. Maybe it will not seem like the photo but the expression and style will come forth and even if the face is not the same you will gain confidence in your strokes.

2) Draw with all the attention to make the most resembling drawing, comparing constantly with the reference. This is imo the most boring one but is absolutely necessary if you want to achieve the likeness to the photo that is so difficult to achieve.

After every face you have to make a critic to your drawing and detect the errors and think of ways you can correct them.

Other webs are useful, like Pinterest but you have to treat it like a guilty pleasure, you have to draw 20 AI generated faces to do 1 Pinterest face.

> B-but le AI, i-is le bad!
Don't care, I'm a tradchad using what is in my hands to enjoy drawing beautiful people I encounter in my daily life.
Picrel is what I can achieve to draw with a fuedpen, no previous pencil structure, all in one sitting, directly done, Kim Jung Gi style.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
This are the first steps. Once you are confident with this you must go and at social events find a way to portrait people. It is easy if you are good and people will beg you to draw them so is a win-win situation, you practice, they get a photo of a portrait that you keep in your notebook.

Drawing irl people gets you incredible gains and is a real good social skill. Lots of gorgeous women have begged me to portrait them in various places it's really a superpower if you are good at it.

This is what worked for me to gitgud at drawing faces. Honestly all the advice you have got is crap but follow your own criterion first.

Picrel is example of drawing I did of an AI face trying to put as much expression as possible using watercolor. I remember it did not end up as the photo as much but you really must practice expression because if not your portraits will end up stiff and forced. The ideal portrait combines precision and expression to various amounts, depending on the end result you want.

last_replies.name: Anonymous

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>6377769
you can't generate interesting designs if you aren't already growing an design sense based in your knowledge and practice, is not a healthy aproach trying to force it because you will over-exaggerate the designs wich is the common problem in all the shitty OC designs you see out there.
Stick to the basics and converge with your style, if your style is based in generic influences, then just stick with that and do not force it beyond your safe zone because you will be regret it later, because is a comic. In fact you must synthesize your style to make it fast and clean and without thinking too much, because again is a comic and you are working alone.
Stick to the basics, translate your character descriptions in easy shapes and well know clothes for you, or some that you can replicate. That's why a lot of designs are just random generic clothes like school uniforms, armors, suits, that have a lot of references to check, and the rest are just generic character hairstyles and accesories that complement their descriptions. Use basic color armonies based on the characters personalities (sasuke is blue dark and naturo yellow orange because da', is obvious, same as goku and vegeta)
Also for a comic you shouldn't try to find a specific style out there, is the one that you already manage, if you dont like, bad for you but that's what you have, that's what you are, work on that.
I know i'm repeating my words but is because is important, a lot of people try to aspire to an ideal of aesthetics that they don't handle but that comes out with time and work, not from the start, and even less for a comic where you have to leave the drawing part as smooth and manageable as possible for yourself in favor of the narrative, because if you dont then bad things can happen, like just getting stuck because you can't keep it up with the workflow, or go

Narrative is the most important aspect, if you have let say... some elder warrior guy that know some martial arts, make it like you know, bald with beard, or a old skin with few muscles, or a lot, traditional martial arts clothes, etc, simple.
Most of the design desitions are not based in your particular ideas of each character but from the whole lore and context of the story, naturo is ninja modern world and that enough justification to have hinata wearing a fucking generic sweatshirt, and that's it, luffy is literally a guy with an open shirt and jeans pants, red blue and yellow from the scarf, and that's it.
Theeen you work on the details, theen you add shapes and things to complement your character, then you add the hat to luffy because he is a pirate or a ocean man, his life is on the sea, then you add the scarfs because that looks like he's been in troubles, he could be a pirate.
Just think in that, make it the way you already draw, then be creative in the designs later based in your strong lore that you already have

threads.com:
This thread is dedicated to master studies, where you copy artwork you admire as a form of study. They are the quickest way to improve and learn about any fundamental you are having problems with. If you need to work on your hands, copy hands from other artists, and if you're having trouble with rendering, make careful studies of paintings with lighting you admire. Studies can be quick or long. You can even copy anatomy books like Bridgman, Morpho, and Hogarth. The type of studies you want to do depend on your personal goals and the types of problems you are grappling with.

Artists of all levels are welcome. Critiques and redlines are encouraged.

>>6376102
>I've always wanted to try Prismacolors over Copics, what set of markers would you recommend?
I started off with the Cool Greys that were sold to me in art school. Later on, I bought the 48 color pack, the Warm Greys pack & others.

If you have the money, I would suggest buying the 48 Color Pack, both Warm & Cool Greys, & the Skin Tones pack. Don't make the mistake of thinking you won't need any "redundant" markers, they'll dry up on you if you use them often enough. They're pretty expensive, so scour the internet for any coupons you can use for blick or AC Moore. I saved a small fortune with a 50% off coupon once.

Oh, & ALWAYS make sure that the caps are SECURELY ON when you aren't using them. That, & the ones that have been made in the past decade have these weird caps that make it hard to pull off, so twist them, DON'T pull. You could damage you fingers & the marker.

>And what type of paper weight are you using for your color?
Canson Mixed Media. Basically, use any mixed media paper, HOWEVER, make sure to slide a sheet of printer paper under it. A lot of the time, the markers will bleed through the paper, & even seep into the page below.

"Hey, you were our fifth pick but the other four never showed up so you can come it you want" sums up my entire career and higher education

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
If you want to learn to make comics then no course will be more valuable than just diving in and making comics on your own. There's no such thing as "comics writing", it's just writing like anything else. Drawing experience has nothing to do with having attended drawing classes. Pick up your pencil and start drawing. Doesn't matter what. Get your practice if you want to draw comics. Get used to the idea of drawing a lot, because that's what comics involve: a LOT of drawing.

Anyway I'd argue a comic book course is a waste of time. There's no value in such a thing, so do something, anything, else. Again, if you're interested in making comics, then just start. Don't waste your time with a course on it, because it will teach you nothing you couldn't have learnt on your own. You can get 100% of the value you would have gotten from the class by sitting outside the lecture hall drawing comics then approaching the students as they finish the class to meet people.

last_replies.com:
>>6367801
When someone praises me I usually respond with criticism of them, ideally in the same domain but if they aren't active there I'll try to find something as close as possible in which they are.
Praise is traditionally considered a signal that they have recognized your superiority in some respect. When this is the case, by criticizing them in turn you are recognizing their inferiority, reinforcing and protecting your place in the hierarchy.
However, note I said "traditionally" because despite that common understanding, typically people praise for the opposite reason: a patronizing sentiment to signal that they are ABOVE you. In this case, criticizing becomes even more critically useful as it closes that gap and indicates that you understand their flaws and thus their vulnerabilities; a warning that you are not to be trifled with and a direct rebuke to their assumed superiority.

>>6376076
What's this obsession with 3d come from? There are few situations where 3d is feasible, for deadline reasons. It simply takes more time to set up than is reasonable for a manga series to make extensive use of it. There are few examples of it and most of those are experiments. I can think of the Gantz guy, I can think of the Negima guy (uses 3d for the school setting) and I can think of Prison School guy (who demonstrated its use in an illustration, but we don't actually know if it's used in the production of the pages themselves). I hate seeing restraints that don't sense DOF-wise
It's so clear to me when an artist has drawn a pose, and then added some shackles or handcuffs on after the fact. I can see instantly when a restraint or garment can easily removed or thwarted with a simple movement, which defeats the whole purpose of bondage if you ask me.
Bondage is kind of a passion for me so i enjoy seeing it done well.

As for non-pornographic? I hate seeing lazy crossovers between franchised characters that are taken completely seriously and don't even attempt to adhere to the source material.
I'm alright with franchised characters and OCs as long as an effort is made to keep them coherent with the world they're supposed to be set in.
I hate seeing people bend the rules so much that they might as well have just created their own original work, because I love seeing people be creative and hate seeing a bunch of otherwise creative ideas wasted on worlds/settings that were not designed to accomodate them.

RESIZE YOUR IMAGES TO ~1000 PIXELS wide using one of the following methods:

Read the sticky

Tab S8+ owner here. Samsung tabs are pretty much the only decent iPad competitors. last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
this is one of those questions that can have a lot of answers that are irrelevant to others because it depends on the kind of art you want to do and what part. whether your works are grounded in contemporary reality, or it's fictional of our own creation, or it's based on mythology or history, or it's based on fandoms, whether the history is meant to be an idealized version that illustrates a moral or simply a recounting of facts. or it could be sequential work.
the person who painted op pic is not in the same frame of mind as someone like botticelli or an anime artist who just wants to show "cool" things or big tits.
for generating ideas for designs such as clothing, tools, accessories, creatures, it's more simplistic because you can look up visual inspirations that you already know are generally related to what you want.
